title: Free-to-play PvP

properties.name: description
properties.value: This article serves as an overview of the free-to-play guides on player-versus-player activities, account builds, and other related topics.

content:
This article serves as an overview of the free-to-play guides on player-versus-player activities, account builds, and other related topics.

Contents

  • 1 Guides
    • 1.1 Overviews
    • 1.2 Advanced topics
  • 2 Account builds
    • 2.1 One defence
    • 2.2 Medium defence
    • 2.3 High defence
  • 3 Activities
    • 3.1 Dangerous
    • 3.2 Safe
  • 4 Changes
    • 4.1 Future updates
    • 4.2 Comparison with RuneScape 2
      • 4.2.1 Items
      • 4.2.2 Spells
      • 4.2.3 Locations
      • 4.2.4 Minigames
      • 4.2.5 Miscellaneous
  • 5 See also

Guides[edit | edit source]

Overviews[edit | edit source]

  • Free-to-play combat pure guide: an introduction to the combat pure account builds and PvP in general.
  • Free-to-play account builds: an overview and listing of the viable free-to-play builds.
  • One-defence pure (free-to-play): an overview and listing of the 1 defence combat pure accounts.

Advanced topics[edit | edit source]

  • Free-to-play PvP equipment: a detailed comparison of the free-to-play items relevant to PvP combat. Includes typical loadouts for various account builds and activities.
  • Free-to-play PvP techniques: an overview of the techniques used in PvP combat.
  • Free-to-play PvP culture: descriptions of activities, locations, behaviours, and slang relevant to the free-to-play PvP culture.

Account builds[edit | edit source]

Main article: Free-to-play account builds

One defence[edit | edit source]

Main article: One-defence pure (free-to-play)

One-defence combat pures sacrifice defensive capabilities to maximize the damage output within their respective combat level brackets. They are arguably the most common type of combat pures made specifically for PvP activities.

Build Skills Viability
Primary Secondary 1-vs-1 Multicombat
Ranged-melee pure High. The most common build for arranged 1-vs-1 combat. High. Consistent damage output with both combat styles. Can tribrid with magic support spells like Snare and Tele Block.
Melee pure Medium to high. The second most common build on high levels. Commonly used for risk fighting. Low. With no ranged attacks, they are extremely vulnerable to binding spells and farcasting.
Magic pure Medium to high early on, low afterwards. Combat spells can outdamage other combat styles early on, but due to their low speed and lack of knockout attacks they are difficult to combo with. Low speed and lack of damage progression past 59 magic level causes magic to be severely outdamaged by other combat styles, leaving magic pures rather ineffective in 1-vs-1 combat outside of the deep wilderness. High. Magic is the most common combat style in the ultra low level clan wars scene, and utility spells such as Snare and Tele Block are extremely useful on higher levels. Magic can also do severe damage to armoured opponents, especially when multiple mages focus on a single opponent.
Strength pure High. High damage output early on with rune warhammers makes them a considerable threat on the low combat level scene. However, their low melee accuracy prevents them from consistently damaging opponents that train defence. Medium early on, low afterwards. Viable on low levels if using ranged and magic switches. However, they cannot overuse ranged and magic attacks without their combat level becoming ranged or magic-based. Lack of fast and accurate melee attacks makes them less viable on higher levels, and without ranged and magic they are even worse than regular melee pures.
Ranged-magic pure Medium early on, low afterwards. They are somewhat viable with ranged-to-magic combo when combat spells are still competitive with melee attacks in terms of the damage output. However, their combos are easier to heal against than in the case of ranged-to-melee switches. High. The most common build in the ultra low level clan wars scene. Later on, they are usually converted to ranged-melee pures and used as tribrids.
Ranged pure Low. Lack of knockout weapons severely limits their ability to perform combos. While they do have high damage output, they might find it difficult to actually knock their opponents out without them running out of supplies first. Commonly used for activities such as ragging rather than legitimate combat. Medium. Somewhat viable due to the high damage output, but lack the flexibility of the hybrid builds.

Medium defence[edit | edit source]

Defence training does not unlock any major free-to-play weapons or other items that would significantly affect the output damage. Because of that, medium defence builds can be thought of as natural progression of the common 1 defence builds such as ranged-melee pure, melee pure, or strength pure. With similar offensive capabilities to their low defence combat pure equivalents, they use the same techniques in combat. However, their higher defensive skills do improve their survivability and allow employing riskier tactics in general.

Currently, the only free-to-play item with a defence requirement that has a strength bonus is the set of gold decorative boots from the Castle Wars minigame. With a strength bonus of +1, these boots are necessary to maximise damage with some melee weapons such as the rune scimitar or rune warhammer.

With access to armours such as rune or green dragonhide, accounts with higher defence levels are especially viable in the deep wilderness and multicombat areas due to their notably higher defensive capabilities.

Build Defence Progression of
Rune pure 40 Ranged-melee pure, melee pure
Adamant pure 30 Ranged-melee pure, melee pure
Strength tank 30, 40 Strength pure

Additionally, clan pures with unrestricted offensive combat skills are common among members of clans that require specific defence levels rather than overall combat levels. Rather than aiming for the lowest possible combat level, clan pures tend to train all combat skills without restriction with the exception of defence capped at a specific limit such as 25.

High defence[edit | edit source]

High defence accounts sacrifice damage output to improve their defensive capabilities. They are often used as support accounts for scouting, luring, ragging, boxing, carrying supplies, and other secondary activities. While rarely used for 1-vs-1 PvP combat, there are some clans that specialize in these types of accounts.

Build Skills Comment
Primary Secondary
Tank Accounts that maximise their defence levels while maintaining some offensive capabilities. Usually high level.
Magic tank Typically used for scouting, luring, and world hopping. Can cast supportive spells such as Snare and Tele Block.
Defence pure Low level accounts that usually train only defence. While they are extremely weak offensively, they can be used for tasks such as scouting, luring, or carrying supplies.
Main Player accounts without any combat skill restrictions, typically used in PvP in the very last combat level brackets.

Activities[edit | edit source]

Dangerous[edit | edit source]

  • Wilderness: a large area north of the kingdoms of Asgarnia and Misthalin where players can engage in combat. Venturing further into the wilderness increases the maximum combat level difference between the opponents, allowing high level players to attack low level players, and vice versa.
  • PvP worlds: dedicated worlds where players can engage in combat in the majority of available locations with the exception of safe areas located near banks and respawn points. The maximum combat level difference between opponents is 15 in most of the dangerous areas, with the wilderness level increasing it even further.

Safe[edit | edit source]

  • Castle Wars: a capture-the-flag minigame where players are separated into two teams. Notable rewards include decorative armour, with the gold decorative boots being the best free-to-play item in the feet slot.
  • Clan Wars: a minigame where clans can arrange fights within a set of arenas. It also offers a free-for-all mode, popular for casual fights. Offers no rewards.
  • Duel Arena: a minigame allowing players to stake coins in arranged duels under specific sets of rules.
  • Last Man Standing: a battle royale minigame where players compete in 1-vs-1 duels to be the last remaining player. The items, prayers, and spells used during the minigame are typically only available to members; there is no game mode that resembles typical free-to-play conditions. Players can no longer earn points in free-to-play worlds, which limits their ability to buy the rewards.

Changes[edit | edit source]

This section includes major updates that affected the free-to-play PvP scene.

Date Changes
11 May 2022
(update)

Bryophyta's staff is a now a free-to-play item.

23 March 2022
(update)

Players can no longer trade in the Wilderness if they are or recently were in combat.

9 March 2022
(update)
  • PJ timer was increased within the single-way combat areas of the Wilderness. Combat interruption prevention was added.
  • Loot Chests were added to the Grand Exchange and the Edgeville bank, significantly increasing their utility on the free-to-play worlds.
  • The cost of unlocking the loot keys was decreased from 5,000,000 coins to 1,000,000 coins.
23 February 2022
(update)

Loot keys were introduced as an opt-in feature. Players can unlock the option to enable loot keys by paying 5,000,000 coins to Skully. When enabled, items dropped by opponents killed by the player are not dropped into the ground, and the player receives a loot key instead. The loot can be retrieved from the loot chest in the Ferox Enclave. Players can hold up to 5 keys, and can modify whether food and other supplies or valuable items are stored in the loot chest or not. Due to the lack of reliable transportation methods to the Ferox Enclave, the utility of the loot keys remained limited to the areas around the enclave itself, as well as the deep Wilderness.

22 September 2021
(update)

The defence bonuses of the items from the green dragonhide armour set and its trimmed variants were significantly lowered. Note that the gilded dragonhide armour was unaffected.

26 May 2021
(update)

The clan system was overhauled and fully launched. The classic clan chats are now available as chat-channels.

21 April 2021
(update)
  • Warhammer wielding requirements where changed from Attack to the equivalent Strength levels.
  • The strength bonuses of warhammers were significantly increased. Now they are slightly lower than the bonuses of the battleaxes from the same materials.
  • Maces are now 1 tick faster, matching the speed of the scimitars.
  • Ranged accuracy penalty was removed from medium helmets and square shields.
  • Ranged accuracy penalty of the full helmets, kiteshields , platelegs, plateskirts and platebodies was increased by roughly 50%.

This update made strength pures a viable build common among low level players.

14 April 2021
(update)

Barronite mace was introduced as a reward from the activities within the Ruins of Camdozaal. With its 4-tick speed, crush-based attack, a strength bonus of +40 and a prayer bonus of +2, this mace can be an effective alternative to the rune scimitar.

17 February 2021
(update)

The competitive mode of the Last Man Standing minigame can no longer be played on the free-to-play worlds, preventing free-to-play players from earning the reward points. A new map based on 4th Age Varrock was introduced.

2 December 2020
(update)
  • Full helmets were introduced to the decorative armours from the Castle Wars rewards shop. They has equivalent bonuses to the steel, mithril and adamant helmets respectively.
  • Red, white, and gold decorative boots with bonuses equivalent to the steel, mithril, and adamant boots respectively were introduced to the Castle Wars Ticket Exchange. With notable melee defence bonuses, they became the best items in the footwear slot. In particular, gold decorative boots offer the highest melee defensive bonuses, as well as strength bonus of +1, which increased maximum melee hit of some weapons such as the rune scimitar (from 25 to 26).
  • Castlewars brew was introduced to the Castle Wars minigame, significantly increasing maximum hits of melee and ranged weapons. Combined with the Castle wars bracelet, it allows to achieve the highest possible hits and DPS values within the free-to-play worlds.
23 July 2020
(update)

The Ferox Enclave respawn can now be unlocked and used by the free-to-play players by paying 5,000,000 coins to Ferox.

16 July 2020
(update)

The Ferox Enclave was introduced to the Wilderness. It is the first settlement with a bank within the free-to-play Wilderness bounds. The town now contains the lobbies of the Clan Wars and the Last Man Standing minigames that were moved there from Al-Kharid, as well as a portal to the Castle Wars lobby. Notable features also include the Pool of Refreshment that can heal players' hitpoints, prayer points, run energy and skill changes.

5 September 2019
(update)
  • The Snare spell was added to the free-to-play worlds.
  • The binding duration of the Bind and Snare spells is no longer halved by the Protect from Magic prayer.
29 August 2019
(update)

The Last Man Standing minigame was overhauled. The Justine's stuff for the Last Shopper Standing shop was introduced with notable free-to-play rewards including the swift blade, a 1-handed 3-tick melee weapon with no combat bonuses. The items from the shop can be bought with points earned through the competitive mode of the minigame.

6 June 2019
(update)
  • The Tele Block spell was added to the free-to-play worlds.
  • The skull status is no longer removed upon entering Clan Wars.
17 August 2017
(update)

Players can now toggle whether the arrows are placed in the inventory or automatically added to the ammunition slot upon picking up by talking to the ranged combat tutor.

10 August 2017
(update)

Castle wars bracelet can now be traded on free-to-play worlds, which increased the viability of the Castle Wars minigame for training by significantly increasing the DPS as well as the number of hitpoints healed by the bandages.

20 July 2017
(update)
  • The Castle Wars minigame was added to the free-to-play worlds. At the time, players could get there by a portal located in Al-Kharid next to the Clan Wars lobby.
  • Some Castle Wars rewards including melee decorative armour were introduced to free-to-play.
  • Zamorak monk robes were added to the free-to-play worlds as uncommon drops from the monks of Zamorak. In particular, Zamorak monk bottom is the only free-to-play item in the legs slot with a magic accuracy bonus, surpassing the leather chaps as the best legs armour for magic combat.
6 October 2016
(update)

Obor was introduced as the first free-to-play boss with the hill giant club as a rare drop. The club provides the same strength bonus as a rune 2h sword and similar accuracy bonuses, but uses crush instead of slash attacks, which makes it more accurate against players wearing plate armour.

4 August 2016
(update)

The Last Man Standing minigame was added. At the time, the lobby of the minigame was located at Al-Kharid, near the Clan Wars lobby.

19 February 2015
(update)

The free-to-play mode was permanently added to the Old School RuneScape.

26 July 2013
(update)

The Edgeville respawn can be unlocked by paying 5,000,000 coins to Krystilia and now works on free-to-play style worlds.

Future updates[edit | edit source]

 This article or section contains information about a scheduled future release or update.
As such, the information is subject to change. This article should consist only of facts included in official Jagex releases and not speculation.
Remember: The Old School RuneScape Wiki is not a crystal ball.
  • Duel Arena is scheduled to be replaced by another PvP minigame.

Comparison with RuneScape 2[edit | edit source]

Since the introduction of Old School RuneScape, a few notable updates affected the free-to-play PvP scene and the combat pure builds.

Items[edit | edit source]

  • Warhammers are now notably stronger and no longer require attack levels. Instead, they require the equivalent strength levels to be wielded. For example, the rune warhammer requires 40 strength to be used, while providing comparable bonuses to the rune battleaxe, which makes it a common knockout weapon among low and early mid level players. This change made the free-to-play strength pure a viable build, and a considerable alternative to the classic melee pures on early combat levels.
  • The attack speed of maces is now on par with scimitars. In particular, barronite mace can be a good alternative to rune scimitar against opponents with a low crush defence bonus if rune scimitar does not allow the player to reach a higher maximum melee hit.
  • Gold decorative boots were introduced as a Castle Wars reward. With bonuses equal to adamant boots, they provide a small strength bonus of +1 that increases the maximum melee hit on some strength levels. In particular, these boots raise the maximum hit of rune scimitars to 26 and rune warhammers to 30 on free-to-play worlds.
  • Hill giant club is a more expensive alternative to the rune 2h sword that can be more accurate against opponents with a low crush defence bonus.
  • Bryophyta's staff is the best magic weapon, offering the highest magic accuracy and defence bonuses on top of considerable melee attack bonuses. The staff stores up to 1,000 nature runes and has a chance to save on the nature rune cost of casting spells such as Snare. It requires 30 Attack and Magic to wield.
  • Zamorak monk robes are now available to free-to-play players. In particular, Zamorak monk bottom replaces
  • Many cosmetic items, including gilded equipment, were introduced to free-to-play worlds. They are commonly used for the so-called risk fights.
  • Skull sceptre holds more changes, can be recharged with bone fragments, and can now autocast Crumble Undead.
  • Chronicle is an item that allows the players to teleport to the Champions' Guild near Varrock without any skill level requirements. Notably, it works on the PvP worlds, but it cannot be used within the wilderness.
  • The melee and ranged defensive bonuses of the green dragonhide armour were reduced. Gilded dragonhide armour offers the same bonuses as the green dragonhide set before the reduction, although it is much more expensive.
  • Loot keys can now be unlocked to receive the entire loot from a defeated opponent as a single key rather than individual items. The keys can be used on a Loot Chest to retrieve the loot.

Spells[edit | edit source]

  • Tele Block is now available on free-to-play worlds.
  • Snare is now available on free-to-play worlds.
  • Bind and Snare binding effects are no longer shortened by the Protect from Magic prayer.
  • Snare can no longer be cast on an opponent currently immune to its binding effect.

Locations[edit | edit source]

  • Ferox Enclave is a small town with a bank added into the wilderness. It is a common regrouping spot for wilderness trips, and it now hosts free-to-play PvP minigames including Clan Wars. It cannot be entered under the effect of the Tele Block spell, encouraging no honour techniques. Area west of the Enclave on W308 is also a common 1-vs-1 combat hotspot.
  • Free-to-play PvP worlds were introduced. Lumbridge and Varrock in the PvP worlds are common 1-vs-1 combat hotspots, similarly to the wilderness area north of Edgeville on W308.
  • Edgeville respawn and Ferox Enclave respawn can be unlocked for a fee as alternatives to the Lumbridge respawn.
  • Wine of Zamorak spawn was added to the Chaos Temple in the deep wilderness.
  • Due to new accounts restrictions, locations such as the wilderness north of Varrock are much less active. Low level wars are usually organized by PvP clans instead of emerging spontaneously.
  • Canoes along the River Lum are now available in free-to-play worlds, providing a transportation method to the Ferox Enclave and the deep wilderness.
  • PJ timer within the single-way combat areas of the wilderness was increased. Combat interruption prevention was added.

Minigames[edit | edit source]

  • The Castle Wars and Duel Arena minigames are now available in free-to-play worlds.
  • The Last Man Standing minigame was added, although its competitive mode is disabled in the free-to-play worlds.
  • The Clan Wars minigame was moved to the Ferox Enclave.

Miscellaneous[edit | edit source]

  • Due to the changes made to warhammers, free-to-play strength pures are now a common combat pure build in low and early mid combat level brackets.
  • Loot keys were introduced to the Wilderness and PvP worlds. After paying 1,000,000 coins to Skully, players can opt-in to receive the loot from the defeated opponents as loot keys. Instead of having to pick up the items off the ground, loot keys allow retrieving all items from a Loot Chest located at the Ferox Enclave, the Grand Exchange or the Edgeville bank.
  • New accounts are restricted from trading, joining chat channels, and entering PvP worlds.
  • Death mechanics were modified.
  • Players in Ironman Mode cannot trade with other players, and do not gain any combat experience when fighting players except for basic spell casting experience. This allows to create optimized combat pures for specific combat level brackets.
  • Clan system was expanded. Classic clan functionalities are now available as chat-channels.
  • Players can now toggle whether the arrows are placed in the inventory or automatically added to the ammunition slot upon picking up by talking to the ranged combat tutor.
  • Third-party clients that offer quality-of-life features such as estimating opponent's hitpoints, combat skills lookup, or maximum hit calculation are now commonly used by players participating in PvP activities. Note that using clients that automate actions such as eating or prayer switching is against the game's rules.

See also[edit | edit source]

  • Free-to-play combat pure guide
  • Free-to-play PvP culture
  • Player killing

rawContent:
This article serves as an overview of the [[free-to-play]] guides on [[player-versus-player]] activities, account builds, and other related topics.

==Guides==

===Overviews===

* [[Free-to-play combat pure guide]]: an introduction to the combat pure account builds and [[PvP]] in general.
* [[Free-to-play account builds]]: an overview and listing of the viable free-to-play builds.
* [[One-defence pure (free-to-play)]]: an overview and listing of the 1 [[defence]] combat pure accounts.

===Advanced topics===

* [[Free-to-play PvP equipment]]: a detailed comparison of the [[free-to-play]] items relevant to [[PvP]] combat. Includes typical loadouts for various account builds and activities.
* [[Free-to-play PvP techniques]]: an overview of the techniques used in [[PvP]] combat.
* [[Free-to-play PvP culture]]: descriptions of activities, locations, behaviours, and slang relevant to the [[free-to-play]] PvP culture.

==Account builds==

{{main|Free-to-play account builds}}

===One defence===

{{main|One-defence pure (free-to-play)}}

One-defence combat pures sacrifice defensive capabilities to maximize the damage output within their respective combat level brackets. They are arguably the most common type of combat pures made specifically for [[PvP]] activities.

===Medium defence===

[[Defence]] training does not unlock any major [[free-to-play]] weapons or other items that would significantly affect the output damage. Because of that, medium defence builds can be thought of as natural progression of the common 1 defence builds such as [[Ranged-melee hybrid (free-to-play)|ranged-melee pure]], [[Melee pure (free-to-play)|melee pure]], or [[Strength pure (free-to-play)|strength pure]]. With similar offensive capabilities to their low defence combat pure equivalents, they use the same techniques in combat. However, their higher defensive skills do improve their survivability and allow employing riskier tactics in general.

Currently, the only [[free-to-play]] item with a [[defence]] requirement that has a strength bonus is the [[Decorative boots (gold)|set of gold decorative boots]] from the [[Castle Wars]] minigame. With a strength bonus of +1, these boots are necessary to maximise damage with some melee weapons such as the [[rune scimitar]] or [[rune warhammer]].

With access to armours such as [[Rune armour|rune]] or [[Green d'hide armour|green dragonhide]], accounts with higher defence levels are especially viable in the deep [[wilderness]] and [[multicombat]] areas due to their notably higher defensive capabilities.

Additionally, [[Clan pure (free-to-play)|clan pures]] with unrestricted offensive combat skills are common among members of [[clan]]s that require specific [[defence]] levels rather than overall [[combat level]]s. Rather than aiming for the lowest possible combat level, clan pures tend to train all combat skills without restriction with the exception of [[defence]] capped at a specific limit such as 25.

===High defence===

High defence accounts sacrifice damage output to improve their defensive capabilities. They are often used as support accounts for scouting, luring, ragging, boxing, carrying supplies, and other secondary activities. While rarely used for 1-vs-1 PvP combat, there are some clans that specialize in these types of accounts.

==Activities==

===Dangerous===

* [[Wilderness]]: a large area north of the kingdoms of [[Asgarnia]] and [[Misthalin]] where players can engage in combat. Venturing further into the wilderness increases the maximum [[combat level]] difference between the opponents, allowing high level players to attack low level players, and vice versa.
* [[PvP world]]s: dedicated [[world]]s where players can engage in combat in the majority of available locations with the exception of safe areas located near banks and [[respawn point]]s. The maximum [[combat level]] difference between opponents is 15 in most of the dangerous areas, with the [[wilderness]] level increasing it even further.

===Safe===

* [[Castle Wars]]: a capture-the-flag minigame where players are separated into two teams. Notable rewards include [[decorative armour]], with the [[Decorative boots (gold)|gold decorative boots]] being the best [[free-to-play]] item in the feet slot. 
* [[Clan Wars]]: a minigame where clans can arrange fights within a set of arenas. It also offers a free-for-all mode, popular for casual fights. Offers no rewards.
* [[Duel Arena]]: a minigame allowing players to stake [[coins]] in arranged duels under specific sets of rules.
* [[Last Man Standing]]: a battle royale minigame where players compete in 1-vs-1 duels to be the last remaining player. The items, prayers, and spells used during the minigame are typically only available to [[members]]; there is no game mode that resembles typical [[free-to-play]] conditions. Players can no longer earn points in free-to-play worlds, which limits their ability to buy the rewards.

==Changes==

This section includes major updates that affected the [[free-to-play]] PvP scene.

{{Subject changes
|date = 11 May 2022
|update = Equipment Rebalance Tier Changes & Poll 76
|change = [[Bryophyta's staff]] is a now a [[free-to-play]] item.
}}
{{Subject changes
|date = 23 March 2022
|update = Guardians of the Rift Launch
|change = Players can no longer trade in the [[Wilderness]] if they are or recently were in combat.
}}
{{Subject changes
|date = 9 March 2022
|update = PJ Timer & New Broadcast Settings
|change =
* [[PJ timer]] was increased within the [[single-way combat]] areas of the [[Wilderness]]. Combat interruption prevention was added.
* [[Loot Chest]]s were added to the [[Grand Exchange]] and the [[Edgeville]] bank, significantly increasing their utility on the [[free-to-play]] worlds.
* The cost of unlocking the [[loot key]]s was decreased from 5,000,000 coins to 1,000,000 coins.
}}
{{Subject changes
|date = 23 February 2022
|update = Nex Achievements and Loot Keys
|poll = 
|change = [[Loot key]]s were introduced as an opt-in feature. Players can unlock the option to enable loot keys by paying 5,000,000 [[coins]] to [[Skully]]. When enabled, items dropped by opponents killed by the player are not dropped into the ground, and the player receives a loot key instead. The loot can be retrieved from the [[loot chest]] in the [[Ferox Enclave]]. Players can hold up to 5 keys, and can modify whether food and other supplies or valuable items are stored in the loot chest or not. Due to the lack of reliable transportation methods to the [[Ferox Enclave]], the utility of the loot keys remained limited to the areas around the enclave itself, as well as the deep [[Wilderness]].
}}
{{Subject changes
|date = 22 September 2021
|update = Wilderness & Equipment Rebalance Changes
|poll = 
|change = The defence bonuses of the items from the [[green dragonhide armour]] set and its trimmed variants were significantly lowered. Note that the [[gilded dragonhide armour]] was unaffected.
}}
{{Subject changes
|date = 26 May 2021
|update = Clans Full Launch
|poll = 
|change = The [[clan]] system was overhauled and fully launched. The classic clan chats are now available as [[chat-channel]]s.
}}
{{Subject changes
|date = 21 April 2021
|update = Fishing Trawler Improvements and Equipment Rebalance: Part One
|change = * [[Warhammer]] wielding requirements where changed from [[Attack]] to the equivalent [[Strength]] levels.
* The strength bonuses of [[warhammer]]s were significantly increased. Now they are slightly lower than the bonuses of the [[battleaxe]]s from the same materials.
* [[Mace]]s are now 1 tick faster, matching the speed of the [[scimitar]]s.
* Ranged accuracy penalty was removed from [[medium helmet]]s and [[square shield]]s.
* Ranged accuracy penalty of the [[full helmet]]s, [[kiteshield]]s , [[platelegs]], [[plateskirt]]s and [[Platebody|platebodies]] was increased by roughly 50%.

This update made [[Strength pure (free-to-play)|strength pures]] a viable build common among low level players.
}}

{{Subject changes
|date = 14 April 2021
|update = Below Ice Mountain
|change = [[Barronite mace]] was introduced as a reward from the activities within the [[Ruins of Camdozaal]]. With its 4-tick speed, crush-based attack, a strength bonus of +40 and a prayer bonus of +2, this mace can be an effective alternative to the [[rune scimitar]].
}}
{{Subject changes
|date = 17 February 2021
|update = 8th Birthday Event and LMS Changes
|change = The competitive mode of the [[Last Man Standing]] minigame can no longer be played on the [[free-to-play]] worlds, preventing [[free-to-play]] players from earning the reward points. A new map based on 4th Age [[Varrock]] was introduced.
}}
{{Subject changes
|date = 2 December 2020
|update = Settings Rework and the last of Poll 73
|change = * [[Full helmet]]s were introduced to the [[decorative armour]]s from the [[Castle Wars]] rewards shop. They has equivalent bonuses to the steel, mithril and adamant helmets respectively.
* [[Decorative boots (red)|Red]],  [[Decorative boots (white)|white]], and  [[Decorative boots (gold)|gold decorative boots]] with bonuses equivalent to the steel, mithril, and adamant boots respectively were introduced to the [[Castle Wars Ticket Exchange]]. With notable melee defence bonuses, they became the best items in the [[footwear]] slot. In particular, [[Decorative boots (gold)|gold decorative boots]] offer the highest melee defensive bonuses, as well as strength bonus of +1, which increased [[maximum melee hit]] of some weapons such as the [[rune scimitar]] (from 25 to 26).
* [[Castlewars brew]] was introduced to the [[Castle Wars]] minigame, significantly increasing [[maximum hit]]s of melee and ranged weapons. Combined with the [[Castle wars bracelet]], it allows to achieve the highest possible hits and DPS values within the [[free-to-play]] worlds.
}}
{{Subject changes
|date = 23 July 2020
|update = Poll 71 and Ferox Enclave Updates
|change = The [[Ferox Enclave respawn]] can now be unlocked and used by the [[free-to-play]] players by paying 5,000,000 coins to [[Ferox]].
}}
{{Subject changes
|date = 16 July 2020
|update = Ferox Enclave
|change = The [[Ferox Enclave]] was introduced to the [[Wilderness]]. It is the first settlement with a [[bank]] within the [[free-to-play]] [[Wilderness]] bounds. The town now contains the lobbies of the [[Clan Wars]] and the [[Last Man Standing]] minigames that were moved there from [[Al-Kharid]], as well as a portal to the [[Castle Wars]] lobby. Notable features also include the [[Pool of Refreshment]] that can heal players' hitpoints, prayer points, run energy and skill changes.
}}
{{Subject changes
|date = 5 September 2019
|update = PvP Balancing, LMS, and Elf Graphics
|change = * The [[Snare]] spell was added to the [[free-to-play]] worlds.
* The binding duration of the [[Bind]] and [[Snare]] spells is no longer halved by the [[Protect from Magic]] prayer.
}}
{{Subject changes
|date = 29 August 2019
|update = Last Man Standing (2019)
|change = The [[Last Man Standing]] minigame was overhauled. The [[Justine's stuff for the Last Shopper Standing]] shop was introduced with notable [[free-to-play]] rewards including the [[swift blade]], a 1-handed 3-tick melee weapon with no combat bonuses. The items from the shop can be bought with points earned through the competitive mode of the minigame.
}}
{{Subject changes

|update = PvP Changes and Deadman Beta
|change = * The [[Tele Block]] spell was added to the [[free-to-play]] worlds.
* The [[Skull (status)|skull status]] is no longer removed upon entering [[Clan Wars]].
}}
{{Subject changes
|date = 17 August 2017
|update = Runes and Ammunition & Log In Screen Competition!
|change = Players can now toggle whether the arrows are placed in the inventory or automatically added to the [[ammunition slot]] upon picking up by talking to the [[ranged combat tutor]].
}}
{{Subject changes

}}
{{Subject changes

|change = * The [[Castle Wars]] minigame was added to the [[free-to-play]] worlds. At the time, players could get there by a portal located in [[Al-Kharid]] next to the [[Clan Wars]] lobby.
* Some [[Castle Wars]] rewards including melee [[decorative armour]] were introduced to [[free-to-play]].
* [[Zamorak monk robes]] were added to the [[free-to-play]] worlds as uncommon drops from the [[monks of Zamorak]]. In particular, [[Zamorak monk bottom]] is the only [[free-to-play]] item in the [[legs slot]] with a magic accuracy bonus, surpassing the [[leather chaps]] as the best legs armour for magic combat.
}}
{{Subject changes

===Future updates===
{{Future}}

*[[Duel Arena]] is scheduled to be replaced by another [[PvP]] [[minigame]].

===Comparison with ''RuneScape 2''===

Since the introduction of ''Old School RuneScape'', a few notable updates affected the [[free-to-play]] PvP scene and the combat pure builds.

====Items====

* [[Warhammer]]s are now notably stronger and no longer require [[attack]] levels. Instead, they require the equivalent [[strength]] levels to be wielded. For example, the [[rune warhammer]] requires 40 strength to be used, while providing comparable bonuses to the [[rune battleaxe]], which makes it a common knockout weapon among low and early mid level players. This change made the [[Strength pure (free-to-play)|free-to-play strength pure]] a viable build, and a considerable alternative to the classic [[Melee pure (free-to-play)|melee pures]] on early combat levels.
* The attack speed of [[mace]]s is now on par with [[scimitar]]s. In particular, [[barronite mace]] can be a good alternative to [[rune scimitar]] against opponents with a low [[crush]] defence bonus if [[rune scimitar]] does not allow the player to reach a higher [[maximum melee hit]].
* [[Decorative boots (gold)|Gold decorative boots]] were introduced as a [[Castle Wars]] reward. With bonuses equal to [[adamant boots]], they provide a small strength bonus of +1 that increases the [[maximum melee hit]] on some strength levels. In particular, these boots raise the maximum hit of [[rune scimitar]]s to 26 and [[rune warhammer]]s to 30 on [[free-to-play]] worlds.
* [[Hill giant club]] is a more expensive alternative to the [[rune 2h sword]] that can be more accurate against opponents with a low [[crush]] defence bonus.
* [[Bryophyta's staff]] is the best magic weapon, offering the highest magic accuracy and defence bonuses on top of considerable melee attack bonuses. The staff stores up to 1,000 [[nature rune]]s and has a chance to save on the nature rune cost of casting spells such as [[Snare]]. It requires 30 [[Attack]] and [[Magic]] to wield.
* [[Zamorak monk robes]] are now available to [[free-to-play]] players. In particular, [[Zamorak monk bottom]] replaces 
* Many [[Free-to-play cosmetic items|cosmetic items]], including [[gilded equipment]], were introduced to [[free-to-play]] worlds. They are commonly used for the so-called risk fights.
* [[Skull sceptre (i)|Skull sceptre]] holds more changes, can be recharged with [[bone fragment]]s, and can now [[autocast]] [[Crumble Undead]].
* [[Chronicle]] is an item that allows the players to teleport to the [[Champions' Guild]] near [[Varrock]] without any skill level requirements. Notably, it works on the [[PvP world]]s, but it cannot be used within the [[wilderness]].
* The melee and ranged defensive bonuses of the [[green dragonhide armour]] were reduced. [[Gilded dragonhide armour]] offers the same bonuses as the green dragonhide set before the reduction, although it is much more expensive.
* [[Loot key]]s can now be unlocked to receive the entire loot from a defeated opponent as a single key rather than individual items. The keys can be used on a [[Loot Chest]] to retrieve the loot.

====Spells====

* [[Tele Block]] is now available on [[free-to-play]] worlds.
* [[Snare]] is now available on [[free-to-play]] worlds.
* [[Bind]] and [[Snare]] binding effects are no longer shortened by the [[Protect from Magic]] prayer.
* [[Snare]] can no longer be cast on an opponent currently immune to its binding effect.

====Locations====

* [[Ferox Enclave]] is a small town with a bank added into the [[wilderness]]. It is a common regrouping spot for wilderness trips, and it now hosts free-to-play PvP [[minigame]]s including [[Clan Wars]]. It cannot be entered under the effect of the [[Tele Block]] spell, encouraging ''no honour'' techniques. Area west of the Enclave on [[World|W308]] is also a common 1-vs-1 combat hotspot.
* [[Free-to-play]] [[PvP world]]s were introduced. [[Lumbridge]] and [[Varrock]] in the [[PvP world]]s are common 1-vs-1 combat hotspots, similarly to the [[wilderness]] area north of [[Edgeville]] on [[World|W308]].
* [[Edgeville respawn]] and [[Ferox Enclave respawn]] can be unlocked for a fee as alternatives to the [[Lumbridge respawn]].
* [[Wine of Zamorak]] spawn was added to the [[Chaos Temple (hut)|Chaos Temple]] in the deep [[wilderness]].
* Due to [[Free-to-play PvP culture#New accounts restrictions|new accounts restrictions]], locations such as the [[wilderness]] north of [[Varrock]] are much less active. Low level wars are usually organized by [[PvP]] [[clan]]s instead of emerging spontaneously.
* [[Canoe]]s along the [[River Lum]] are now available in free-to-play worlds, providing a transportation method to the [[Ferox Enclave]] and the deep [[wilderness]].
* [[PJ timer]] within the [[single-way combat]] areas of the [[wilderness]] was increased. Combat interruption prevention was added.

====Minigames====

* The [[Castle Wars]] and [[Duel Arena]] minigames are now available in [[free-to-play]] worlds.
* The [[Last Man Standing]] minigame was added, although its competitive mode is disabled in the [[free-to-play]] worlds.
* The [[Clan Wars]] minigame was moved to the [[Ferox Enclave]].

====Miscellaneous====

* Due to the changes made to [[warhammer]]s, [[Strength pure (free-to-play)|free-to-play strength pures]] are now a common combat pure [[Free-to-play account builds|build]] in low and early mid [[combat level]] brackets.
* [[Loot key]]s were introduced to the [[Wilderness]] and [[PvP world]]s. After paying 1,000,000 [[coins]] to [[Skully]], players can opt-in to receive the loot from the defeated opponents as [[loot key]]s. Instead of having to pick up the items off the ground, loot keys allow retrieving all items from a [[Loot Chest]] located at the [[Ferox Enclave]], the [[Grand Exchange]] or the [[Edgeville]] bank.
* New accounts are [[Free-to-play PvP culture#New accounts restrictions|restricted]] from trading, joining chat channels, and entering [[PvP world]]s.
* [[Death]] mechanics were modified.
* Players in [[Ironman Mode]] cannot trade with other players, and do not gain any combat experience when fighting players except for basic spell casting experience. This allows to create optimized [[Free-to-play combat pure guide|combat pures]] for specific [[combat level]] brackets.
* [[Clan]] system was expanded. Classic clan functionalities are now available as [[chat-channel]]s.
* Players can now toggle whether the arrows are placed in the inventory or automatically added to the [[ammunition slot]] upon picking up by talking to the [[ranged combat tutor]].
* Third-party clients that offer quality-of-life features such as estimating opponent's hitpoints, combat skills lookup, or [[maximum hit]] calculation are now commonly used by players participating in [[PvP]] activities. Note that using clients that automate actions such as eating or prayer switching is against the game's rules.
